Editor’s choice paper Palladium nanoparticles on dendrimer-containing supports as catalysts for hydrogenation of unsaturated hydrocarbons Edward A. Karakhanov a ⁎ Anton L. Maximov a b Elena M. Zakharyan a b Anna V. Zolotukhina a Andrey O. Ivanov b a Department of Petroleum Chemistry and Organic Catalysis, Moscow State University, Moscow, 119991, Russian Federation Department of Petroleum Chemistry and Organic Catalysis Moscow State University Moscow 119991 Russian Federation b Institute of Petrochemical Synthesis, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, 119991, Russian Federation Institute of Petrochemical Synthesis Russian Academy of Sciences Moscow 119991 Russian Federation ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A method for the synthesis of encapsulated palladium nanoparticles of size to 5nm in the pores of specially prepared supports, which are polymer networks based on poly(amidoamine) (PAMAM) and poly(propylene imine) (PPI) dendrimers, is proposed. It was found that particle size distributions, as well as catalytic activity and selectivity of the resulting materials in hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds significantly depend on the structure features of the support (nature and generation of dendrimer, size and rigidity of a crosslinking agent, and the use of a template in the synthesis). The best values of specific activity were achieved for styrene (86,000h−1), phenylacetylene (103,700h−1) and 1,3-cyclohexadiene (65,000h−1). It was established that the catalysts based on PAMAM dendrimers, synthesized in the presence of template, were superior to their analogues, synthesized without template, in terms of activity. An inverse relationship was observed for catalysts, based on PPI dendrimers, for all substrates with the exception of phenylacetylene. The catalysts based on palladium nanoparticles, encapsulated into dendrimer networks, can be repeatedly used without a noticeable loss of activity. Keywords Palladium nanoparticles Selective hydrogenation Dendrimer networks PAMAM PPI 1 Introduction Hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds is one of the most important processes in the current petrochemical industry. Thus, hydrogenation of olefins allows to obtain stable diesel fuel additives with high cetane numbers and to stabilize gasoline pyrolyzates [1,2] in order to avoid the polymerization of olefins, which is inevitable at operation and storage and accompanied by fuel performance degradation. The selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene, which is a poison for polymerization catalysts, is more preferential from economics point of view, than its separation from reaction products [1,3–5]. Hydrogenation of acetylene and diene fragments in C2 C5 hydrocarbons allows to avoid the subsequent polymerization and oxidation of these products [1,3–6]. Selective hydrogenation also plays an important role in the processes of fine organic synthesis, where both various metal complexes and heterogeneous catalysts can be used [7,8]. In this connection development of efficient and selective hydrogenation catalysts that can be easily recycled used is a problem of considerable current importance. Heterogeneous catalysts, that are traditionally used in industry, often require severe reaction conditions, under which it is very difficult to reach high selectivity for a required product, and high metal loading in system. The homogeneous catalysts, used in fine organic synthesis, are characterized by high values of specific activity and selectivity; at the same time, they have a number of disadvantages, such as high costs, low stability and impossibility for recycling. Thus, the promising is development of the systems that simultaneously combine advantages of both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. Systems based on noble metal nanoparticles encapsulated into dendrimers, being spherically symmetrical macromolecules with a regular branched structure, may appear as catalysts of this kind. Dendrimers as matrices for the synthesis of metal nanoparticles have a number of advantages [9], such as the possibility to obtain materials with a uniform particle distribution in the volume and control the size of nanoparticles being formed. In applications to catalysis, the separation and recycling of dendrimer-stabilized nanoparticles can be realized due to the fractional solubility of the dendrimer ligand [10–12]. Recently catalysts, based on dendrimer-encapsulated nanoparticles, have been widely used in petrochemical and organic synthesis. They were applied to the hydrogenation of CC double bonds [13–16] and reduction of nitro- and carbonyl groups [16,17]; in reactions of hydroformylation [18,19], amination [20], oxidation [16] and carbonylation [21]; and Suzuki [22–25], Heck [26,27] and Sonogashira cross-coupling reactions [28], as well as various cycloaddition, condensation and alkylation reactions [16,17,29]. Nevertheless, these catalysts have their own disadvantages: they can be stored and used only as colloidal solutions, and they rapidly lose activity at recycling [22]. Therefore, heterogenization of dendritic catalysts is a problem of considerable interest. Thus, there was proposed an approach, suggesting chemical immobilization of poly(propylene imine) (PPI) or poly(amidoamine) (PAMAM) dendrimers in pores or on surfaces of silica [22,30–35], carbon nanotubes [12] or insoluble polymers, as cross-linked poly(styrene) [36–38]. Earlier we have developed an approach for synthesis of heterogeneous supports based on PPI and PAMAM dendrimers by their crosslinking with the use of special agents (diisocyanates and diepoxides), whose size and rigidity are responsible for the final properties of the resulting materials [39–45]. The possibility of regulating the particle size (from 1 to 2.5nm) in these materials was reached by varying the size and rigidity of the linker, and the generation of dendrimers. Here, we report the results of the use of another approach, allowing to synthesize catalysts with a large particle size: the initial supports of PPI and PAMAM networks are prepared in the presence of a block-copolymer of ethylene oxide and propylene oxide as a template. We present data on the synthesis of these materials and on their efficiency in the hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds. For comparison, we also consider the results obtained with catalysts synthesized using non-templated networks. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The following reagents were used as initial and reference substances: 1-octene C8H16 (Reachim, Reagent Grade); styrene C6H5CHCH2 (Aldrich, ≥99%); p-methylstyrene p-CH3C6H4CHCH2 (Aldrich, 96%); p-tert-butylstyrene p-(CH3)3CC6H4CHCH2 (Aldrich, 94%); phenylacetylene (Aldrich, 98%); 2,5-dimethyl-2,4-hexadiene (CH3)2CCHCHC(CH3)2 (Aldrich, 98%); and dicyclopentadiene C10H12 (Aldrich, 97%). Their purity was monitored by gas–liquid chromatography (GLC). Methanol CH3OH (Acros Organics, 99+%); ethanol C2H5OH (IREA 2000, analytical grade); chloroform CHCl3 (Ekos-1, Reagent Grade); tetrahydrofuran (THF) C4H8O (Chimmed, 99.5%); dimethylformamide (DMF) HC(O)N(CH3)2 (Chimmed, Chemical Grade) were used as solvents. Chloroform was purified by distillation from molecular sieves 4Å; THF was distilled over calcium hydride, and DMF was distilled over molecular sieves in a vacuum with the azeotropic distillation of water in the presence of benzene. The following substances were used for the synthesis of catalysts based on dendrimers: second-generation poly(amidoamine) dendrimer with an ethylenediamine core (PAMAM-G2, PAMAM(NH2)16, MW∼3256.18) synthesized in accordance with a published procedure [46]; third-generation poly(propylene imine) dendrimer with a diaminobutane core (PPI-G3, DAB(NH2)16, MW∼1686.79) synthesized in accordance with a published procedure [47]; 3,3′-dimethoxy-4,4′-diphenyl diisocyanate p-(H3COC6H3NCO)2 (DMDPDI) (Aldrich, tech., 85%); poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(propylene glycol)-block-poly(ethylene glycol) (Pluronic 123) (C2H4O)20(C3H6O)70(C2H4O)20 with the number average molecular weight Mn≈5800 (Aldrich); poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(propylene glycol)-block-poly(ethylene glycol) (Pluronic 127) (C2H4O)101(C3H6O)56(C2H4O)101 with the average-number molecular weight Mn≈12,000 (Aldrich); and palladium(II) acetate Pd(OAc)2 (Aldrich, 99.9%). They were used without additional purification. Dispersities of dendrimers used were calculated as ratio of number-average molecular weight (Mn ) to weight-average molecular weight (Mw ), retrieved from the corresponding mass-spectra, and achieved 99% for DAB(NH2)16 and ∼100% for PAMAM(NH2)16 respectively. 2.2 Methods and instrumentations 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopic analysis was performed on Avance Bruker instrument with operating frequency of 400.13MHz. The chemical shifts δ (ppm) are given with reference to TMS (0.00ppm). For aqueous solutions, 3-(trimethylsilyl)propanesulfonic acid (DSS) was used as an internal standard (δ 0.015ppm). D2O and DMSO-d 6 were used as solvents. Mass spectrometry was used for the determination of the purity of synthesized PPI dendrimers and the conversion of N-isopropylacrylamide. Mass-spectra were recorded on Agilent LC–MS 1100 SL instrument with electrospray ionization (ESI), in positive ion detection mode. Samples were prepared as solutions in methanol (Acros Organics, 99+%) and distilled water with a concentration of ∼1mg/mL. The electrospray needle voltage was 3.5kV. The drying gas temperature was 250°C, and the flow rate was 11L/min. Fourier transform IR spectroscopic analysis was performed on Nicolet IR2000 instrument (Thermo Scientific) with the use of a horizontal attenuated total reflectance (HATR) accessory supplied with a 45° ZnSe crystal for different wavelength ranges with a resolution of 4cm−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was carried out on Kratos Axis Ultra DLD and LAS-3000 instruments equipped with an OPX-150 hemispherical retarding-field electron-energy analyzer. The X-radiation of an aluminum anode (Al Kα=1486.6eV) was used for the excitation of photoelectrons at a tube voltage of 12kV and an emission current of 20mA. Photoelectron peaks were calibrated on the C 1s line of carbon with a binding energy of 284.8eV. The quantitative determination of palladium in the samples was performed by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP AES) with the aid of an IRIS Interpid II XPL instrument (Thermo Electron Corp., USA) with both radial and axial viewings at wavelengths of 310 and 95.5nm. The studies by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were carried out on LEO912 AB OMEGA transmission electron microscope. Micrographs were processed and average particle sizes were calculated with the Image J software. A ChromPack CP9001 gas chromatograph, equipped with a capillary column (SE-30 grafted phase, 30m×0.2mm) and flame-ionization detector, was used for analysis of substrates and reaction products. Chromatograms were recorded and analyzed on a computer with the use of the Maestro 1.4 software. Conversion was determined by changes in the relative peak areas (in%) of the substrates and products. 2.3 Synthesis of dendrimers-based hybrid materials 2.3.1 Synthesis of the DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI(1/1) material [34] DAB(NH2)16 dendrimer (1g, 0.6mmol) and 50mL of THF were placed into a 100-mL round-bottom flask, equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a reflux condenser. Then, 1.4g (4.75mmol) of 3,3′-dimethoxy-4,4′-diphenyldiisocyanate was added while stirring. The reaction was carried out at 70°С for 12h. After the reaction completed (the complete dissolution of the cross-linking agent and the appearance of light yellow precipitate at the bottom instead of the red-brown dendrimer particles), the mixture was evaporated on a rotor evaporator with the formation of 2.07mg of milk-white powder (yield of 86%). IR (cm−1): 3310 (NHst in NHC(O)); 2930 (CHst); 2855 (CHst, CH2 Nst); 1661, 1589, 1513 (COst in NHC(O)); 1470 (NHδ, CH2δ, XNHδ); 1396 (CH2δ); 1320, 1246, 1203, 1173, 1130, 1029 (CNst в NHC(O)); 945 (CHδ in aromatics); 814 (CCδ in aromatics); 715 (NHδ); 688 (CH2γ). XPS (eV): 1192.7 (CN), 1197.9 (CO) (Еb C 1s, 71.7%); 399.5 (N 1s, 15.4%); 943.8 (ON), 949.2 (Еb O 1s, 12.9%). 2.3.2 Synthesis of the EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI(1/3) material PAMAM(NH2)16 dendrimer (768mg, 0.236mmol) and 50mL of absolute THF were placed into a 100-mL single-neck flask, equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a reflux condenser. In this case, dendrimer was swollen but not dissolved. Then 711mg (2.4mmol) of dimethoxydiphenyldiisocyanate in 50mL of absolute methanol was added while stirring. The reaction was carried out for 12h at 70°C; thereafter, the reaction mixture was evaporated on a rotary evaporator at 50°C. The product was isolated with as a white powder a yield of 892mg. IR (cm−1): 3325 (NHst in NHC(O)); 2929 (CHst); 2856 (CHst, CH2 Nst); 1627, (COst in NHC(O)); 1547 (NHδ, CH2δ, CNHδ); 1462, 1431 CH2δ); 1261, 1157, 1113, 1038 (CNst in NHC(O)); 874, 820 (CHδ in aromatics); 768, 729, 710, 658 (CCδ in aromatics). XPS (eV): 284.5 (C (C Caryl, C-Haryl) 1s, 29.2%), 285.7 (C (NCH2CH2 N) 1s, 32.8%), 287.7 (C ( CH2 NHCO) 1s, 7.1%), 288.9 (C ( C(O)NH) 1s, 2.1%); 399.5 (N 1s, 14.1%); 531.2 (O (C O) 1s, 6.9%), 533.0 (O (O CH3, CO⋯HN) 1s, 7.8%). 2.3.3 Synthesis of the meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI(1/1) material Polymer Pluronic 123 (1g, ∼0.17mmol) and 5mL of DMF were placed in a 10-mL round-bottom flask. To the solution obtained, 360mg of K2CO3 was added with stirring. The reaction was carried out at 150°C with stirring. Then, 100μL (1.6mmol) of iodomethane was added and the reaction was performed for 12h at the specified temperature; thereafter, DMF was distilled off on a rotary evaporator. The methylated polymer was dissolved in 15mL of chloroform and separated from K2CO3 by decantation. DAB(NH2)16 (1g, 0.6mmol) was added to the solution of Pluronic123-Me2 in chloroform; thereafter, the mixture was homogenized for 12h at room temperature. After the completion of stirring, the chloroform was distilled off on a rotary evaporator with the formation of brown oil. The weight of the conglomerate obtained was 1.92g (yield, 96%). The DAB(NH2)16*Pluronic 123 conglomerate was suspended in 50mL of THF. 3,3′-Dimethoxy-4,4′-diphenyl isocyanate (1.4g, 4.75mmol) was added to the suspension while stirring. The reaction was carried out at 70°C for 12h. After the reaction completed, the mixture was evaporated on a rotary evaporator with the formation of an ocherous yellow precipitate. The material obtained was washed with water and ethanol to remove the polymer and dried in air. The weight of the product was 1.86g (74%). IR (cm−1): 3321 (NHst in NHC(O)); 2990 (CHst in aromatics); 2940 (CHst); 2869 (CHst, CH2 Nst); 1685, 1587, 1509 (COst in NHC(O)); 1465 (NHδ, CH2δ, X-NHδ); 1396 (CH2δ); 1245, 1201, 1171, 1127, 1094, 1027 (CNst in NHC(O)); 927 (CHδ in aromatics); 813 (CCδ in aromatics); 780 (NHδ). XPS (eV): 284.9 (C 1s, 69.2%); 398.3 (N 1s, 4.6%); 531.5 (O 1s, 26.2%). 2.3.4 Synthesis of the meso-EN-PAMAM-G2-DMPDI(1/1) material The synthesis was carried out in accordance with a procedure analogous to that described in Section 2.3.3. As the initial substances, 1g (∼0.08mmol) of a Pluronic 127 polymer, 360mg of K2CO3, and 100μL (1.6mmol) of iodomethane in 10mL of DMF were taken. PAMAM(NH2)16 dendrimer (1g, 0.31mmol) was added to the resulting methylated polymer dissolved in 10mL of chloroform. For the subsequent crosslinking, the conglomerate PAMAM(NH2)16*Pluronic 127 formed was suspended in 50mL of THF and introduced into reaction with 0.735g (2.48mmol) of 3,3′-dimethoxy-4,4′-diphenyl isocyanate. The weight of the product as white powder was 1.287g. IR (cm−1): 3328 (NHst in NHC(O)); 2937 (CHst); 2852 (CHst, CH2 Nst); 1731, 1649, 1591 (COst in NHC(O)); 1529 (NHδ, CH2δ, CNHδ); 1489, 1392, 1334 (CH2δ); 1236, 1203, 1136, 1074, 1028 (CNst in NHC(O)); 955, 845 (CHδ in aromatics); 799, 735, 650 (CCδ in aromatics). XPS (eV): 284.6 (C (C Caryl, C Haryl) 1s, 23.0%), 286.1 (C (NCH2CH2 N) 1s, 43.9%), 288.1 (C ( C(O)NH) 1s, 5.0%); 399.5 (N 1s, 8.5%); 530.9 (O (C O) 1s, 3.1%), 532.6 (O (O-CH3, CO⋯HN) 1s, 16.4%). 2.3.5 Synthesis of the DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI(1/1)-Pd(1/8) material [34] DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI(1/1) (1g) and 50mL of absolute chloroform were placed in a 100mL round-bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a reflux condenser. To the suspension obtained, 426mg (1.9mmol) of Pd(OAc)2 was added. The reaction was carried out for 12h at 70°C. In this case, the color of the reaction mixture changed from red-ocher to dark brown. After the reaction completed, the suspension was evaporated on a rotary evaporator. The resulting substance was dark brown powder with a weight of 1.2g (yield of 95%), which was then placed in a 50mL flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a reflux condenser and suspended in a mixture of 35mL of methanol and 25mL of chloroform. To the suspension obtained, 722mg (19mmol) of sodium borohydride was added. In this case, the reaction mixture darkened and violent gassing was observed. The reaction was carried out for 12h at 70°C. After the reaction completed, the resulting mixture was evaporated to dryness on a rotary evaporator, and the precipitate formed was washed with water and methanol by centrifugation for the removal of sodium tetraborate residues and dried in air. The substance obtained was black powder with a weight of 1.2g (yield of 96%). If necessary, 1μL of a solvent was added per milligram of the substrate. The autoclave was tightly closed, filled with hydrogen to a required pressure, and connected to a thermostat. The reaction was carried out at 80°C with intense stirring for a required time, after which the reactor was cooled below room temperature. The reaction products were analyzed by gas–liquid chromatography. The activity of each catalytic reaction is reported as specific activity (SA), which was calculated as a ratio of the reacted substrate to the metal loading, expressed in moles, per unit of time: The samples of DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd and meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd were re-used in hydrogenation of styrene and phenylacetylene, respectively. In both cases, 0.5mg of catalyst and 750μL of substrate were placed in a thermostatically controlled steel autoclave equipped with a glass insertion tube and a magnetic stirrer. The autoclave was tightly closed and filled with hydrogen to a pressure of 10 or 30 atm. for styrene-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd or phenylacetylene-meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd pair, respectively; thereafter, it was connected to the thermostat. The reaction was carried out at 80°C with intense stirring for 15min. After the reaction completed, the stirring was turned off and the autoclave was cooled below room temperature in a cold water bath and opened; thereafter, the reaction mixture was diluted with ∼2mL of hexane for the better sedimentation of the catalyst. In the case of phenylacetylene, the diluted reaction mixture was additionally allowed to stand for 15–20min. The solution with reaction products was separated by decantation and analyzed by gas–liquid chromatography. Catalyst, remained in the test tube, was repeatedly used without additional loading or purification. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of heterogeneous catalysts based on PPI and PAMAM dendrimers We used the second-generation poly(amidoamine) (PAMAM) dendrimer PAMAM(NH2)16 and the third-generation poly(propylene imine) dendrimer DAB(NH2)16 for design of polymer network matrices as carriers for palladium nanoparticles (Fig. 1 ). The conformationally rigid 3,3′-dimethoxy-4,4′-biphenylene diisocyanate, p-(H3COC6H3NCO)2 (DMDPDI), was used as a crosslinking agent. To study the effect of the degree of crosslinking on the activity of catalysts, we synthesized two types of carriers with NCO/NH2 ratios of 1/3 and 1/1. Also we additionally synthesized dendrimer networks in the presence of a Pluronic P123 (EO20PO70EO20) template in order to obtain larger pores in the structure of carriers. Table S1 summarizes the physical chemical properties of the materials obtained. The IR spectroscopic and XPS data confirmed the presence of CH2CH2N [48], NHC(O)NH [49–52], and C6H4 [48] fragments in the structures of carriers; this indicated the successful proceeding of the reaction between amino groups of dendrimers and isocyanate groups of crosslinking agent. According to XPS data, a higher oxygen content and, simultaneously, a lower nitrogen content of the surface of EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI(1/3), as compared with those of DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI(1/1), correlated with the presence of amide groups in the PAMAM dendrimer structure. According to the TEM data, the dendrimer networks obtained had a uniform laminar structure without any inclusions (Figs. S1–S4). The use of a template led to the formation of networks with a more uniform morphology (Figs. S2 and S4) and an increase in the surface O/N ratio, whereas the carbon content of the carriers remained almost unchanged. This can be related to both the presence of the oxygen-containing aryl linkers on the surface of carriers and the incomplete removal of Pluronic during the purification of dendrimer networks. Palladium nanoparticles of were encapsulated into the dendrimer matrices in accordance with a previously published procedure [41]. Palladium acetate was chosen as a metal source, and chloroform was used as a solvent because of the high solubility of the above mentioned salt and the swelling of polymers, containing urethane groups, in this solvent. Palladium was reduced to a zero-valent state with the use of sodium borohydride, whereas a dendrimer simultaneously acted as a complex-forming agent and the stabilizer of particles formed. The synthesized catalysts were characterized by TEM, XPS, IR spectroscopy, and ICP AES. Table 1 summarizes their physical chemical properties. Based on the TEM data, we found that the nature of a dendrimer and the use of a template in the synthesis of the support had a substantial influence on the average particle size and particle size distribution (Figs. 2–5 , Table 1). Thus, the samples based on PPI dendrimers (Figs. 2 and 3) were characterized by high density and uniform particle distribution through the volume of the carrier. On the contrary, in materials based on PAMAM dendrimers (Figs. 4 and 5), particles were concentrated as agglomerates and characterized by a narrower particle size distribution. In both cases, the addition of a template resulted in a broadening of the distribution and an increase in the average particle size, which was greater for the catalyst based on PPI dendrimers (Table 1, Figs. 2 and 3). Thus, the average particle size in meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd was 5.2nm (vs. 2.1nm for DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd), and a fraction of larger particles with a diameter of 11–16nm appeared. Probably, the template not only separated dendrimers here, but also structured them around itself in a specific manner to change the local parameters of cell cavities. Herein, in the matrices based on PPI dendrimers, characterized by a high degree of crosslinking, both templated and not templated, Pd nanoparticles were located mainly in cavities between dendrimers fixed by rigid biaryl linkers, that may be attributed to particle size, comparable or sufficiently exceeding that for PPI dendrimers of the 3rd generation. As for PAMAM dendrimers, having a low degree of cross-linking, it seems, that the use of a template only increased the cavity widths between the dendrimer moieties. As seen from Fig. 5, it led to the additional growth and agglomeration of particles and to a broadening of the particle size distribution. In this case Pd nanoparticles might be formed both between the end branches of dendrimers (being stabilized here by CO and NH groups) and in cavities between the dendrimers. It should also be noted, location of Pd nanoparticles between dendrimer branches may be possible due to distortion of dendrimer molecules, resulted from nanoparticles formation and growth; herein Pd nanoparticles being seemed to draw apart the dendrimer branches, as illustrated in several works [17,53,54]. Nonetheless, this assumption may be referred mostly to small particles (0.5–1.5nm in diameter). In spite of fact, that nominal Pd proportion was the same for all samples (1 mole of Pd per 2 moles of the dendrimer end amino groups), found weight Pd content after reduction sufficiently differs from sample to sample and does not have any regularities (Table 1). Nonetheless, these data show, in what extent dendritic networks are able to retain Pd, depending on the dendrimer’s nature and synthetic procedure (with or without polymeric template). Thus, the lowest weight Pd loading was observed for meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd (3.13%), while the highest one was for DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd (11.20%). meso-EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd was characterized by slight increase in Pd content (6.01%) in comparison with EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd (4.09%). These results indirectly correlate with the difference in mean particle diameters between templated and non-templated catalysts for both PPI and PAMAM dendrimer-based systems. According to the XPS data (Table 1, Fig. 6 ), the samples based on both the PPI and PAMAM dendrimers contain palladium in both reduced (Pd0 3d5/2, 335.0-335.7eV) [55–58] and oxidized forms (PdOx 3d5/2, 336.5–336.7eV; PdO 3d5/2, 337.2eV) [59–62], as well as Pd2+ ions, bound with amino or carbonyl groups (338–339eV at Pd 3d5/2) [55,56,63–65]. O 1s spectra of all of the catalysts exhibit a signal corresponding to the Pd-O bond due to the presence of PdOx surface oxides in the Pd 3d spectra [66]. The presence of oxides in the spectra of the reduced samples can be explained by the ready oxidizability of palladium nanoparticles in the course of storage in air [67] and by the incomplete reduction of the initial samples. Higher binding energies for Pd in DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd and EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd may be attributed to less particle size (2.1–2.2nm) and, as a consequence, to higher partial positive charge on the surface [68–72]. The total atomic concentrations of palladium on the catalyst surfaces weakly correlate with the weight concentrations of palladium determined by ICP AES analysis (Table 1). In the case of catalysts based on the PPI dendrimers, the use of a template at the stage of the carrier synthesis led to a decrease in both the surface and bulk palladium contents (Pd washed out), whereas the PAMAM dendrimers exhibited an inverse effect. Nevertheless, the use of a template method led to a notable increase in the ratios between the surface and bulk concentrations of palladium (C s/C v) for the both types of dendrimers. These ratios were 1.09 and 0.83 for the samples of meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd and meso-EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd, respectively, vs. 0.68 and 0.25 for DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd and EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd, respectively. Analogously, with the use of mesoporous dendritic matrices for the synthesis of palladium nanoparticles, we observed an increase in the ratios Pd0/(PdOx + Pd2+) in both PPI and PAMAM dendrimers. It was 5.13 for meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd and 1.07 for meso-EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd vs. 1.42 and 0.39 for DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd and EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd, respectively. Herein both PdO and partial oxide PdOx were assumed as “PdOx”, while both Pd0 and surface alloy Pd0/PdOx were analogously assumed as “Pd0”. The main difference for Pd0/PdOx and PdOx species is in the local Pd/O ratios on the surface: PdOx species contains both PdPd and PdO bonds in approximately equal quantities in both surface and sub-surface layers (the most important for XPS) [72]. In Pd0/PdOx species PdPd bonds sufficiently dominate over the PdO bonds (approximately as 10: 1) [73]; therefore Pd0/PdOx in their its nature and electronic properties is much closer to Pd0, than to oxidized Pd states. A total absence of pure Pd0 on the surface of meso-EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd may be attributed both to stabilization of Pd nanoparticles by carbonyl groups along with amino groups of PAMAM dendrimers and to more open structure of templated dendritic matrix, facilitating particles exposure to air oxidation. Similar tendency, as appearance of additional oxidation states, is also observed for meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd. A small shift of the binding energies of carbon and nitrogen relative to the typical binding energy values (284.8 and 398.9eV, respectively [48,74,75]) in the spectra of the samples can be explained by partial electron transfer from nitrogen atoms to neutral or partially charged palladium nanoparticles [76,77] and by electron density displacement to carbonyl oxygen atoms in the amide groups of the PAMAM dendrimers [49–52]; this is confirmed by the deconvolution of the corresponding C 1s and N 1s lines for all of the catalyst samples. 3.2 Hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds in the presence of the heterogeneous catalysts based on PPI and PAMAM dendrimers The synthesized materials were tested as catalysts for the hydrogenation of different unsaturated compounds: olefins, dienes, and phenylacetylene. The specific activity (SA) of the catalysts was calculated as the amount of a reacted substrate per mole of Pd per unit of time according to the formula: S A = ν s u b s t r . * c o n v . ν P d * t In the hydrogenation of linear 1-octene, the catalysts based on the PAMAM dendrimers exhibited the greatest activity (∼2600–2700h−1) (Table 2 ); thus, the sample of meso-EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd made it possible to reach a nearly quantitative conversion even after 1h. At the same time, the DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd catalyst afforded a conversion of only 20% under analogous conditions at a specific activity of 300h−1 in spite of a much higher metal content. We believe that this phenomenon can be explained in terms of the more expanded and open structure of PAMAM dendrimers, as compared with that of PPI dendrimers. This assumption was confirmed by a reaction performed in the presence of the meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd catalyst prepared with the use of a template; as a consequence, this catalyst contained cavities and particles of larger sizes. The conversion of 1-octene in the presence of this catalyst was 38% at a much higher substrate/Pd ratio (∼5400), and the specific activity (∼2000h−1) was comparable with that of the materials based on the PAMAM dendrimers (Table 2). Replacement of an alkyl substituent in the substrate molecule by an aromatic one conjugated with a double CC bond led to a notable increase in both the hydrogenation rate and the specific catalyst activity. Thus, the conversion in styrene hydrogenation on DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd at the ratio substrate/Pd=12400 was 86%, or it was 100% in the presence of meso-EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd at the ratio substrate/Pd=23060 (Table 3 ). In this case, ethylbenzene was the only reaction product. As in the hydrogenation of 1-octene, the catalysts based on PAMAM dendrimers were much superior to those based on PPI dendrimers in terms of activity in the hydrogenation of styrene. At the same time, the effects of templates used for the synthesis of carriers on the catalyst activity changed (Table 3). Thus, DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd was only slightly inferior in activity to its mesoporous analogue, meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd; their turnover frequencies varied within a range of 42,000–48,000h−1. The difference between EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd and meso-EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd was as high as ∼25,000h−1 at a specific activity of meso-EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd higher than 92,000h−1. We assume that this change in the behaviors of catalysts on going from 1-octene to styrene is simultaneously related to both geometric (the flat conjugated molecule of styrene is difficult to penetrate a denser matrix based on the PPI dendrimers) and electronic factors (the simultaneous adsorption of both a CC double bond and a conjugated aromatic ring) and also a change in a polarity ratio between the carrier and the substrate. Introduction of additional alkyl substituents into the p-position to the CC bond of the styrene molecule led to a decrease in the activities of all of the synthesized samples (Fig. 7 ); this is typical of the catalysts based on dendrimers [9,14]. When passing from styrene to p-methylstyrene, the activity of meso-EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd and both of the catalysts based on PPI dendrimers or EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd decreased by a factor of ∼2–4 or ∼10, respectively. That is, in spite of a less sterically hindered structure of the carrier, the latter was also inferior to the catalysts based on PPI dendrimers in performance characteristics. In this case, it appears, that a ratio between polarities is the main factor responsible for the activity of EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd. A further increase in the size and hydrophobicity of a substituent (as in p-tert-butylstyrene) also led to a decrease in the conversions and specific activities, as was exemplified with the catalysts based on the PPI dendrimers (Fig. 7, Table 3); in this case, both of the samples exhibited a nearly exponential relationship. Using DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd as an example, we found that, in principle, dendritic catalysts can be re-used in the hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds (Fig. 8 ). The test for the recycling was performed analogously to a standard hydrogenation procedure in the presence of palladium catalysts. For the better sedimentation of the catalyst and the prevention of mechanical losses, the reaction products were additionally diluted with n-hexane, which is a poor solvent for dendrimers [78]. The resulting solution was separated by decantation, and the remaining catalyst was used in the subsequent cycles without additional loading and regeneration. We found that DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd can be re-used six or more times. A small decrease in conversion in the subsequent cycles was related to an initially low catalyst loading and inevitable mechanical losses in the course of decantation. The total turnover number of the reaction was 42025. The use of phenylacetylene as a substrate dramatically changed the situation (Table 4 ). meso-EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd catalyst, which is characterized by high yields and activities with respect to terminal alkenes (1-octene and styrenes), did not afford a 100% conversion of phenylacetylene even at the relatively low ratio substrate/Pd≈4000; in this case, selectivity for styrene was extremely low. An increase in the ratio substrate/Pd to ∼12,000 made it possible to attain acceptable selectivity for styrene; however, in this case, the conversion was only 50%, which is unsuitable for practical applications. On the contrary, the catalysts based on PPI dendrimers made it possible to reach high selectivity for styrene (90–95%) at nearly quantitative conversions (90–100%) (Table 4). meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd catalyst obtained with the use of a template exhibited a considerably higher efficiency, as compared with that of its non-mesoporous analogue: its reaction turnover frequency at a 100% conversion and 96% selectivity for styrene (a substrate/Pd ratio of ∼15,400) was ∼62,000h−1, which was much higher than that for the samples based on PAMAM dendrimers (24,200h−1). The high selectivity in the case of meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd can be related to its original low activity in the hydrogenation of styrene (Table 3) and a high local ligand/metal ratio (N/Pd, Table 1) in comparison with that in the non-mesoporous analogue. We assume that this abrupt change in the behavior of catalysts upon the replacement of styrene by phenylacetylene is primarily caused by a change in the electronic properties of the substrate and, as a consequence, in its adsorption on the surface of palladium nanoparticles. The triple bond CC in the phenylacetylene molecule is conjugated with an aromatic ring; at the same time, it concentrates a much higher electron density, as compared with that on the double bond CC in the molecule of styrene. Consequently, the bond with the acetylene proton becomes partially polarized (in particular, due to the weak M-effect of the aromatic ring) [78]. It becomes even greater polarized due to interactions with the basic amino groups of dendrimers, which were found more effective in the case of PPI dendrimers (the basicity of PAMAM dendrimers it is lowered due to the involvement of about a half of amino groups in conjugation with the carbonyl groups). On the other hand, the presence of a large number of carbonyl groups in the molecules of PAMAM dendrimers facilitates the formation of oxidized species on the surface of palladium nanoparticles, which was confirmed by the XPS data (Table 1). It leads simultaneously to a decrease in both catalyst activity (due to the need for the preliminary reduction of metal sites and, as a result, the appearances of an induction period [33]) and selectivity because of the repeated π-adsorption of the previously formed styrene. The surface of the palladium nanoparticles in the catalysts based on PPI dendrimers not only contains a smaller amount of oxidized species, but also it is additionally enriched by electrons due to interactions with the amino groups of dendrimers. Therefore, the adsorption of substrates and intermediate reaction products becomes more selective. Note that an increase in the activity of the catalysts was observed in the samples based on both PPI and PAMAM dendrimers; this was related to an increase in the size of nanoparticles and, as a result, a decrease in their dispersity and total specific surface area. Analogous tendencies were observed earlier in the hydrogenation of 1-butyne in the presence of Pd/Al2O3 with piperidine additives [79] and in the hydrogenation of 1-hexyne in the presence of palladium nanoparticles stabilized by sodium bis(2-ethylhexyl)sulfosuccinate (AOT) [80]. An increase in activity with decreasing the dispersity of a supported metal was noted for phenylacetylene in the presence of different heterogeneous catalysts based on palladium [81] and 3-butyn-1-ol in the presence of Pd/MCM-41 [82]. Similar result were obtained in [83–85], in particular, for diphenyl hydrogenation on heterogeneous Pd catalysts (e.g. Pd/Al2O3) [84,85]. It was also found that there is an optimum size of metal particles that is characterized by a maximum catalyst activity [86,87]. This phenomenon can be explained by a set of both electronic and geometric factors [74,83,84,88,89]. These latter imply a specific atomic arrangement, favorable for the adsorption of a substrate and its subsequent hydrogenation: in the case of palladium, these are the [111] faces, the size of which increases with the diameter of the particles [82,83,87,89,90]. In this case, the specific catalyst activity depends on the structure of metal nanoparticles, which, in turn, depends on their size [82,83]. As a consequence, the plane-parallel π- and di-σ-adsorption occurs on the wide [111] faces with a larger probability with the subsequent formation of alkenes [88]. However, the dissociative perpendicular adsorption, which leads to the isomerization (in the case of linear alkynes [91]) or oligomerization of a substrate, is predominantly characteristic of small particles (<6nm) due to an uncompensated partial positive charge on the surface (electronic factors) and an insufficient number of landing sites for the plane-parallel adsorption. It should be noted that neither oligomerization nor isomerization was observed with the use of the catalysts synthesized based on dendrimer networks in spite of a relatively small average particle diameter (2–5nm). This fact can be explained by partial electron density transfer from the tertiary atoms of the amino groups of dendrimers to the surface of palladium nanoparticles, which carries an uncompensated partial positive charge, and by the creation of steric hindrances due to a cross-linked dendrimer matrix. It seems, that a further decrease in the activity of a catalyst with increasing the particle size, which was reported previously [86,87], is related to a decrease in the total specific surface area of the metal particles and, as a consequence, a decrease in the number of active “working” atoms. With the use of catalysts based on PPI dendrimers as an example, it was also found that an increase in the pressure of hydrogen makes it possible to perform the quantitative hydrogenation of phenylacetylene at considerably higher substrate/Pd ratios; in this case, selectivity for styrene remained high (90–95%) (Table 4). Another advantage of these hybrid materials over a classical Pd/C catalyst [92–94] or a Lindlar catalyst [95] consists in the retention of high selectivity for styrene at long reaction times (Fig. 9 ). The main problem of the hydrogenation of phenylacetylene in the presence of palladium catalysts is the gradual washing out of the metal because of the complex formation of palladium nanoclusters with substrate molecules due to the mono-σ-adsorption of the substrate [96–98]. In particular, the polarization of a bond with the acetylene proton, which is stronger in the case of PPI dendrimers, and, consequently, an additional increase in electron density on the CC bond facilitate the mono-σ-adsorption of phenylacetylene. Nevertheless, we found that the palladium catalysts based on dendrimer networks can be re-used many times (Fig. 10 ). Thus, with the use of the meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd catalyst, we observed only a small decrease in the activity after eight reaction cycles due to the mechanical losses of the catalyst; in this case, selectivity for styrene varied over a range of 90–95% (Fig. 10). The total turnover number of the reaction was 120460. In the recycling dendritic catalysts in the phenylacetylene hydrogenation, it was important to properly select a solvent and to subsequently settle the reaction mixture for better catalyst sedimentation. In this case, the solvent (as a rule, of liquid C5 C7 alkanes) was required not only for the effective precipitation of a dendrimer network to prevent the mechanical losses of the catalyst, but also for the decomposition of phenylacetylene complexes with palladium, which were formed in the course of the reaction. For this purpose, the reaction mixture was additionally settled before decantation (for separation from the catalyst) and the subsequent GLC analysis. Hydrogenation of diene hydrocarbons and α,β-unsaturated compounds occurred in a different manner. Here, the yield of reaction and the specific catalyst activity depended on both the type of the dendrimer used and the general structure of the support and by the geometric and electronic characteristics of the substrate. Thus, in the case of materials based on the PAMAM dendrimers, the sample obtained with the use of a template exhibited a considerably higher activity, in comparison with that of a non-mesoporous analogue, in the hydrogenation of methyl acrylate and 2,5-dimethyl-2,4-hexadiene: for the latter, the turnover frequency of the reaction was higher than 43,000h−1 (Table 5 ). A higher conversion of methyl acrylate, as compared with that of 2,5-dimethyl-2,4-hexadiene, and a similar activity of EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd at a lower substrate/Pd ratio can indicate an affinity between the substrate and the corresponding structural units of the carrier. At the same time, it is difficult to trace analogous behaviors of the catalysts based on PPI dendrimers. Thus, meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd was found much more effective than DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd in the hydrogenation of methyl acrylate and 1,3-cyclohexadiene (specific activity of 160000h−1 at the ratio substrate/Pd≈53,000–56,500 and a hydrogen pressure of 10 atm.); simultaneously, it exhibited an anomalously low activity toward 2,5-dimethyl-2,4-hexadiene (Table 5): conversion in its presence was no higher than 15% after 1h even at a relatively low substrate/Pd ratio (5950). In this case, DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd was much more active than EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd in the hydrogenation of 2,5-dimethyl-2,4-hexadiene, whereas meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd was much more active than meso-EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd in the hydrogenation of methyl acrylate. In general, note that, as in the case of phenylacetylene, a decrease in the dispersity of particles facilitates an increase in the catalyst activity in the hydrogenation of dienes. The decrease in activity on going from 1,3-cyclohexadiene to the more bulky and branched 2,5-dimethyl-2,4-hexadiene can be explained by steric hindrances that appear on substrate diffusion through a dendrimer matrix. An analogous trend for the more compact methyl acrylate may be related to its electron-acceptor properties, which interfere adsorption and the subsequent hydrogenation of the double CC bond. An increase in the hydrogen pressure to 30 atm facilitated a significant increase in the activities of meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd toward methyl acrylate (to 180,000h−1) and of DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd toward 2,5-dimethyl-2,4-hexadiene and methyl acrylate (quantitative conversions can be reached at reaction turnover frequencies up to 62,000h−1). Distribution of diene hydrocarbons hydrogenation products was almost independent of the structure of a catalyst, and it weakly changed with changes in the substrate/Pd ratio (Scheme 1 ). Thus, 1,3-cyclohexadiene gave cyclohexene (with 90–100% selectivity) and cyclohexane, whose fraction regularly decreased as the catalyst loading was decreased. 2,5-dimethyl-2,4-hexadiene gave the following four products: 2,5-dimethyl-2-hexene, 2,5-dimethylhexane, 2,5-dimethyl-cis-3-hexene, and 2,5-dimethyl-trans-3-hexene with total selectivity for monoenes up to 99%. The yield of each particular isomeric alkene (Scheme 1) depended on the stability of corresponding intermediates in accordance with the classical reaction scheme of the hydrogenation of diene hydrocarbons [33,99]. An increase in the reaction time and a decrease in the substrate/Pd ratio facilitated an increase in the yield of an alkane and a trans-1,4-addition product (2,5-dimethyl-trans-3-hexene); this fact is indicative of the predominant thermodynamic control of reaction. At the same time, an increase in the substrate/Pd ratio led to an increase in the fraction of the 1,2-addition product, 2,5-dimethyl-2-hexene (an increase in the fraction of kinetic of control). Methyl propionate (a 1,2-addition product) was the only product of methyl acrylate hydrogenation; the CO bond did not undergo further hydrogenation. The hydrogenation of unconjugated dicyclopentadiene occurred stepwise (Scheme 2 ). The double bond of former diene, located opposite to the methylene bridge, first became saturated because it is less sterically hindered and more geometrically strained (Fig. 11 ) [100]; in this case, the configuration of the initial dicyclopentadiene was retained. Diene degradation products (cyclopentadiene, cyclopentene, and cyclopentane) were also formed as by-products; as a rule, the total fraction of these products did not exceed 3%. In all cases, dihydrodicyclopentadiene was the main reaction product, which is typical of supported palladium catalysts (Pd/C, Pd/Al2O3, and Pd/SiO2) at short reaction times [101–106]. Selectivity for dihydrodicyclopentadiene in the absence of additional ligands was, on the average, 50–70%. According to published data, the use of catalysts based on nickel [100,101,107–109] and ruthenium [101,107]; Pt, Pd, and Rh blacks [101,107]; and gold [110] and an increase in the pressure of hydrogen [101,102,105] and the reaction time [102–105] led to the predominant formation of tetrahydrodicyclopentadiene. On the contrary, the palladium catalysts synthesized, based on dendrimer networks, allowed us to selectively obtain dihydrodicyclopentadiene, whose fraction among the reaction products was 90–100%, and it did almost not decrease as the hydrogen pressure and the reaction time were increased or the substrate/Pd ratio was decreased (Table 6 ). Analogous results were also obtained by Karakhanov et al. [43], who studied the hydrogenation of unsaturated hydrocarbons in the presence of catalysts based on palladium nanoparticles immobilized in the networks of PAMAM dendrimers. The catalysts based on PAMAM dendrimers exhibited the greatest activity in the hydrogenation of dicyclopentadiene (the turnover frequency of the reaction was 26,000–29,000h−1). DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd also exhibited comparable activity (∼22,000h−1) with the retention of high selectivity for a monoene (92–97%) even at low substrate/Pd ratios (∼1800) in contrast to the catalysts based on PAMAM dendrimers (Table 6). On the contrary, meso-DAB-PPI-G3-DMDPDI-Pd was characterized by anomalously low activity, similar to that obtained earlier in the hydrogenation of 2,5-dimethyl-2,4-hexadiene (Table 5). It seems, that the occurrence of an induction period with the use of this catalyst can be explained by low palladium content and an insufficient number of nanoparticle surface sites suitable for the adsorption and hydrogenation of dicyclopentadiene. We believe that, as in the case of phenylacetylene, the simultaneous use of dendrimers as ligands and supports leads to the enrichment of the surface of palladium nanoparticles in electrons. At the same time, the dendrimer branches and linkers create additional steric hindrances to prevent the repeated adsorption of dihydrodicyclopentadiene; because of this, high selectivity is retained. The relatively high fraction of tetrahydrodicyclopentadiene (20%) in the case of meso-EN-PAMAM-G2-DMDPDI-Pd may be explained by a high concentration of oxidized palladium species in this catalyst; as shown earlier, this leads to a noticeable decrease in selectivity for a monoolefin [28] because of electron depletion in particles surface. 4 Conclusions The use of nanostructured ensembles based on crosslinked dendrimers and palladium nanoparticles makes it possible to synthesize highly active and selective catalysts for the hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds. The activity and selectivity of these systems depend on the nature and structure of a dendritic matrix and its affinity for the substrate and on the electronic characteristics of the metal nanoparticles. We found that catalysts based on PAMAM dendrimers are most effective in the hydrogenation of linear alkenes and styrenes, whereas catalysts based on PPI dendrimers exhibit the highest activity and selectivity in the hydrogenation of phenylacetylene. In this case, the materials synthesized with the use of a template (so-called mesoporous catalysts) exhibited maximum selectivity. Selectivity in the hydrogenation of dienes depends only slightly on the support structure, whereas activity simultaneously depends on a combination of steric, electronic, and geometric factors for each substrate–catalyst pair. Palladium catalysts based on dendrimeric networks can be easily separated from the reaction products and re-used in several cycles without significant loss in activity. coredata.dc:description: A method for the synthesis of encapsulated palladium nanoparticles of size to 5nm in the pores of specially prepared supports, which are polymer networks based on poly(amidoamine) (PAMAM) and poly(propylene imine) (PPI) dendrimers, is proposed. It was found that particle size distributions, as well as catalytic activity and selectivity of the resulting materials in hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds significantly depend on the structure features of the support (nature and generation of dendrimer, size and rigidity of a crosslinking agent, and the use of a template in the synthesis). The best values of specific activity were achieved for styrene (86,000h−1), phenylacetylene (103,700h−1) and 1,3-cyclohexadiene (65,000h−1). It was established that the catalysts based on PAMAM dendrimers, synthesized in the presence of template, were superior to their analogues, synthesized without template, in terms of activity. An inverse relationship was observed for catalysts, based on PPI dendrimers, for all substrates with the exception of phenylacetylene. The catalysts based on palladium nanoparticles, encapsulated into dendrimer networks, can be repeatedly used without a noticeable loss of activity.
coredata.dc:title: Palladium nanoparticles on dendrimer-containing supports as catalysts for hydrogenation of unsaturated hydrocarbons
